title.children: ACCC takes Qantas to court for allegedly selling tickets for cancelled flights, ASX to rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Speaking of Qantas, Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones has walked back comments that the government blocked Qatar Airways' request for extra flights to protect the profitability of Qantas. On Monday, Mr Jones told the Australian Financial Review that Qatar Airways was denied its request for additional flights into Australia in order to protect Qantas's profits — despite the airline posting a record pre-tax profit of $2.5 billion last financial year. But speaking on Sky News this morning, he said his comments had been "misconstrued". "I made the completely uncontroversial statement that the Australian government wants to ensure our airline industry is viable and competitive, that it's delivering good services to customers," he said. "A viable airline industry requires a profitable airline industry." When pushed by host Peter Stefanovic for a reason why the government rejected Qatar's application, Mr Jones reiterated that it was about about keeping "all of our airline operators" viable. "This has got away over the last couple of days, and if it's attributed to comments I've made, I've made the uncontroversial comment that we need … all of our airline operators to be viable and profitable in this sector, viable and profitable in this country, he said. " I'm not saying it's [so] profits [are] higher, I'm saying that the airline industry, all of the operators, need to be viable. We have seen in our history what happens when they're not. "We see airlines going falling over, customers and workers … left high and dry, and we don't want to see that." You can read more of this story from political reporter Jake Evans below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Assistant Treasurer backtracks on comment that Qatar Airways was blocked to protect Qantas

featuredLink.title: Minister walks back comments that government intervened to protect Qantas' profits

children.content: Speaking of Qantas,
Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones
has walked back comments that the government blocked Qatar Airways' request for extra flights to protect the profitability of Qantas.
On Monday, Mr Jones told the Australian Financial Review that Qatar Airways was denied its request for additional flights into Australia in order to
protect Qantas's profits
— despite the airline posting a record pre-tax profit of $2.5 billion last financial year.
But speaking on Sky News this morning, he said his comments had been "misconstrued".
"I made the
completely uncontroversial statement
that the Australian government
wants to ensure our airline industry is viable and competitive
, that it's delivering good services to customers," he said.
"A viable airline industry requires a profitable airline industry."
When pushed by host Peter Stefanovic for a reason why the government rejected Qatar's application, Mr Jones reiterated that it was about about keeping
"all of our airline operators" viable.

"This has got away over the last couple of days, and if it's attributed to comments I've made, I've made the uncontroversial comment that we need … all of our airline operators to be viable and profitable in this sector, viable and profitable in this country, he said.
I'm not saying it's [so] profits [are] higher
, I'm saying that the airline industry, all of the operators, need to be viable. We have seen
in our history what happens when they're not.
"We see airlines going falling over, customers and workers … left high and dry, and we don't want to see that."
You can read more of this story from
political reporter Jake Evans
below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) has launched legal action against Qantas for allegedly advertising tickets for more than 8,000 flights it had already cancelled but not removed from sale. The ACCC claims that Qantas kept selling tickets for the flights that were scheduled to depart between May and July 2022 for an average of more than two weeks after the cancellation of the flights — and in some cases, up to 47 days. The competition watchdog also alleges Qantas failed to notify existing ticketholders their flights had been cancelled for an average of 18 days, and up to 48 days, for more than 10,000 flights set to take off between May and July 2022. "This conduct affected a substantial proportion of flights cancelled by Qantas between May to July 2022," the ACCC said. "The ACCC alleges that for about 70% of cancelled flights, Qantas either continued to sell tickets for the flight on its website for two days or more, or delayed informing existing ticketholders that their flight was cancelled for two days or more, or both." Head of the ACCC, Gina Cass-Gottlieb, said the legal action against Qantas comes after a "detailed investigation" into the airline's flight cancellation practices. "We allege that Qantas' conduct in continuing to sell tickets to cancelled flights, and not updating ticketholders about cancelled flights, left customers with less time to make alternative arrangements and may have led to them paying higher prices to fly at a particular time not knowing that flight had already been cancelled," she said. The investigation by the ACCC determined Qantas cancelled almost one in four flights between May and July 2022, with 15,000 out of 66,000 domestic and international flights from airports in Australia in Qantas's published schedule being cancelled. The ACCC's proceedings account for more than 10,000 of those flights. Qantas has been contacted for comment.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas illegally advertised flights that had already been cancelled, ACCC alleges

children.content: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) has launched legal action against
Qantas
for allegedly
advertising tickets for more than 8,000 flights it had already cancelled but not removed from sale
The ACCC claims that Qantas kept
selling tickets for the flights that were scheduled to depart between May and July 2022
for an average of more than two weeks after the cancellation of the flights — and in some cases, up to 47 days.
The competition watchdog also alleges Qantas
failed to notify existing ticketholders their flights had been cancelled
for an average of 18 days, and up to 48 days, for more than 10,000 flights set to take off between May and July 2022.
"This conduct affected a substantial proportion of flights cancelled by Qantas between May to July 2022," the ACCC said.

"The ACCC alleges that for about 70% of cancelled flights, Qantas either continued to sell tickets for the flight on its website for two days or more, or delayed informing existing ticketholders that their flight was cancelled for two days or more, or both."
Head of the ACCC,
Gina Cass-Gottlieb
, said the legal action against Qantas comes after a "detailed investigation" into the airline's flight cancellation practices.
"We allege that Qantas' conduct in continuing to sell tickets to cancelled flights, and not updating ticketholders about cancelled flights,
left customers with less time to make alternative arrangements
and may have led to them
paying higher prices to fly
at a particular time not knowing that flight had already been cancelled," she said.
The investigation by the ACCC determined
Qantas cancelled almost one in four flights between May and July 2022
, with 15,000 out of 66,000 domestic and international flights from airports in Australia in Qantas's published schedule being cancelled.
The ACCC's proceedings account for more than 10,000 of those flights.
Qantas has been contacted for comment.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's not the headline you'll be wanting to see if you're in Victoria or South Australia this morning, but with spring on our doorstep, the energy market operator is warning that much of the national power grid is facing substantial reliability problems in the coming 10 years. The Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO) has released its latest 10-year outlook, and is warning that the outlook for the national grid has worsened since February. AEMO says these reliability problems mean "imminent and urgent investment" is needed, or "the reliability of the National Electricity Market (NEM) will be at risk. But it's not just South Australia and Victoria which are facing issues — the NEM includes all states and territories except for Western Australia and the Northern Territory. So what's behind the reliability problems? A lack of investment in renewable energy generation, storage and transmission as coal-fired power stations shut down. AEMO's chief executive Daniel Westerman says the forecast hotter and dryer summer ahead is a significant risk to the grid. "Breaching the reliability standard doesn't necessarily mean that there will be blackouts ," he told AM. "What it means is that there's not enough electricity supply to meet the standard and that more investment is needed, and that's what we're calling for. "However, we are also saying that this summer, we'll see an elevated risk compared with recent years, and that is primarily because this summer is forecast to be hotter and drier than the last summers. "But it's also because the reliability of our old coal fired generators is at historic lows and plant operators are telling us that that's unlikely to materially improve. "Now, as you'd expect, for this summer, like every summer, AEMO, together with industry and governments are well underway with our preparation to manage these conditions, but we're flagging reliability risks to remain. " You can read more about this story from political reporter Tom Lowrey below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why Victoria and South Australia are at greater risk of power blackouts this summer

featuredLink.title: National energy grid facing peak pressures over hotter months

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: University of North Carolina students are calling for stricter state gun laws after associate professor Zijie Yan was shot dead earlier this week. At the rally, students described hours of terror and confusion during a lockdown and police manhunt that resulted in the arrest of a man who has been charged with first-degree murder and having a gun on educational property. March For Our Lives co-founder David Hogg urged students to take their pain and anger to the ballot box. "The reality is, if we don't mobilise after these things happen, they're going to continue happening," he said. "This is a critical state because this is where change is possible, a lot more than in Washington. "If students at UNC and elsewhere turned out and voted, they could change the state legislature."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: University students rally for gun safety after fatal shooting

children.content: (AP Photo: Hannah Schoenbaum)
University of North Carolina students are calling for stricter state gun laws after associate professor Zijie Yan was shot dead earlier this week.

At the rally, students described hours of terror and confusion during a lockdown and police manhunt that resulted in the arrest of a man who has been charged with first-degree murder and having a gun on educational property.
(AP Photo: Hannah Schoenbaum)
March For Our Lives co-founder David Hogg urged students to take their pain and anger to the ballot box.
"The reality is, if we don't mobilise after these things happen, they're going to continue happening," he said.
"This is a critical state because this is where change is possible, a lot more than in Washington.
"If students at UNC and elsewhere turned out and voted, they could change the state legislature."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ukraine's military has confirmed six Ukrainian servicemen have been killed aboard two helicopters while "carrying out missions." Local media reports the incident occurred near Kramatorsk, where much of the fighting has been taking place since Russia's invasion 18 months ago. Reports suggest the two helicopters were "completely destroyed" and bodies have been found at the crash site. Officials say a service for the men will take place on Thursday local time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ukraine's military confirms multiple deaths after helicopter crash

children.content: Ukraine's military has confirmed six Ukrainian servicemen have been killed aboard two helicopters while "carrying out missions."
Local media reports the incident occurred near Kramatorsk,
where much of the fighting has been taking place since Russia's invasion 18 months ago.
Reports suggest the two helicopters were "completely destroyed" and bodies have been found at the crash site.
Officials say a service for the men will take place on Thursday local time.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The prime minister says he's convinced voters in the crucial state of Tasmania will vote Yes in the Voice referendum. Anthony Albanese will visit Hobart and Launceston on the first full day of campaigning since confirming the poll will be held on October 14. After spending yesterday in Hobart, No campaign leaders will head to Adelaide today — in a further sign Tasmania and South Australia are shaping up to be key states in the vote. Mr Albanese has told Triple-M Radio he's confident the referendum will succeed. "I am convinced Tasmanians will vote Yes," he said. "I will be with the Premier Jeremy Rockliff this morning, and then with Bridget Archer in Launceston this afternoon, both of them being strong Yes supporters."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM: 'Tasmanians will vote Yes'

children.content: The prime minister says he's convinced voters in the crucial state of Tasmania will vote Yes in the
Voice referendum
Anthony Albanese will visit Hobart and Launceston on the first full day of campaigning since confirming the poll will be held on October 14.
After spending yesterday in Hobart, No campaign leaders will head to Adelaide today — in a further sign Tasmania and South Australia are shaping up to be key states in the vote.
Mr Albanese has told Triple-M Radio he's confident the referendum will succeed.
"I am convinced Tasmanians will vote Yes," he said.
"I will be with the Premier Jeremy Rockliff this morning, and then with Bridget Archer in Launceston this afternoon, both of them being strong Yes supporters."
